lesson_title: At Home: Daily Life and Family Talk
objectives: Learn words and phrases to talk about people and things at home.
Practice simple conversations with family members about daily routines.
Understand and use vocabulary related to household chores and activities.

sections.text: Our family is the most important group of people in our life. They live together in our home. Here are the names of common family members.

examples.label: Father
examples.value: Your male parent. He works to support the family.

examples.label: Mother
examples.value: Your female parent. She cares for the home and family.

examples.label: Brother
examples.value: A male sibling. He can be elder or younger.

examples.label: Sister
examples.value: A female sibling. She can be elder or younger.

examples.label: Grandfather
examples.value: Your father's or mother's father. An elder in the family.

examples.label: Grandmother
examples.value: Your father's or mother's mother. An elder in the family.

examples.label: Uncle
examples.value: The brother of your father or mother.

examples.label: Aunt
examples.value: The sister of your father or mother.

examples.label: Cousin
examples.value: The child of your uncle or aunt.

examples.label: Parents
examples.value: Your father and mother together.

usage_examples: My **father** is a hardworking farmer.
My **mother** cooks delicious food for us.
My **elder brother** helps me with my studies.
My **younger sister** loves to draw pictures.
My **grandfather** tells us many old stories.
My **grandmother** makes tasty sweets for festivals.
We are a happy **family** living in one **house**.
My **uncle** and **aunt** often visit our home.
My **cousins** come to play with me.
Every **child** loves their **parents**.
We live with our extended **family** in a joint **household**.
My **father's** name is Ramesh.
My **mother's** sister is my **aunt**.
I have two **brothers** and one **sister**.
Our **grandparents** live with us.

table.title: Family Members
rows: My father works in the field.

subtopics.title: 1.2. Talking About Roles and Relations at Home

sections.text: In our homes, different people have different roles and relationships. We can describe them using these words.

examples.label: Spouse
examples.value: Your partner in marriage (husband or wife).

examples.label: Parent
examples.value: A father or a mother.

examples.label: Child
examples.value: A young boy or girl, a son or a daughter.

examples.label: Neighbor
examples.value: A person who lives next door or very close to your house in the village.

examples.label: Guest
examples.value: A person invited to visit your home.

examples.label: Elder
examples.value: An older person in the family or community.

examples.label: Friend
examples.value: A person you know well and like.

examples.label: Sibling
examples.value: A brother or a sister.

usage_examples: My **parents** take care of our family well.
The **children** of our **neighbor** play with us.
We had a **guest** visit us yesterday from the city.
My aunt and uncle are a happily **married** couple.
It is important to **respect** our **elders** at home and in the village.
My **friend** often comes to our **house** to study.
We always welcome **visitors** to our **dwelling**.
Our **household** is always busy with activities.
My **mother** is a **caring** person.
My **father** is very **responsible** for the family.
I have two **siblings**: one brother and one sister.
Good **neighbors** help each other in times of need.
A **husband** and **wife** are called **spouses**.
The **head of the family** is usually the eldest member.
We have a strong **bond** in our family.

sections.text: Every morning, we do certain things. These are part of our daily routine. We use verbs (action words) to describe these activities.

examples.label: Wake up
examples.value: To stop sleeping.

examples.label: Brush teeth
examples.value: To clean your teeth with a brush.

examples.label: Take a bath
examples.value: To wash your body with water and soap.

examples.label: Eat breakfast
examples.value: To have the first meal of the day.

examples.label: Get ready
examples.value: To prepare yourself, often by wearing clothes.

examples.label: Pray
examples.value: To speak to God.

usage_examples: I **wake up** early in the morning.
First, I **brush my teeth**.
Then, I **take a bath** with fresh well water.
After that, I **eat breakfast** with my family.
My mother **prepares** tea and roti for breakfast.
We all **gather** for breakfast at 7 AM.
My father **drinks** milk in the morning.
My brother **gets ready** for school.
My grandmother **prays** to God every morning.
I **comb my hair** after my bath.
We **wear** our school uniform to get ready.
I **pack my school bag** before leaving.
My mother **wakes me up** at 6 o'clock.
I **wash my face** with cold water.
We **greet** our elders in the morning.

subtopics.title: 2.2. Talking About Afternoon and Evening Activities

sections.text: After school, we come home and do other activities. In the evening, families usually spend time together.

examples.label: Eat lunch
examples.value: To have the midday meal.

examples.label: Do homework
examples.value: To complete school assignments given for home.

examples.label: Play
examples.value: To engage in games or fun activities.

examples.label: Eat dinner
examples.value: To have the last meal of the day.

examples.label: Sleep
examples.value: To rest your body and mind at night.

examples.label: Watch TV
examples.value: To watch programs on the television.

examples.label: Rest
examples.value: To relax or stop working for some time.

usage_examples: After school, I **eat lunch** at home.
Then, I **do my homework**.
In the evening, I **play** with my friends in the field.
We **eat dinner** together as a family.
Before sleeping, I **read** a storybook.
My mother **prepares** dinner after the field work.
We all **sit** together and **talk** in the evening.
My **parents** **rest** after a long day.
I **learn** new things from my grandparents every evening.
Sometimes we **watch TV** after dinner.
My sister **helps** mother in the kitchen.
My father **reads the newspaper** in the evening.
I **go to bed** at 9 PM.
We **chat** about our day during dinner.
My grandfather likes to **take a walk** after dinner.

table.title: Daily Routine Actions
rows: I read a book before bed.

sections.text: Chores are tasks or duties that need to be done regularly at home to keep it clean and organized. Everyone in the family helps with these.

examples.label: Clean the house
examples.value: To make the house neat and free from dirt, often by sweeping or wiping.

examples.label: Wash dishes
examples.value: To clean plates, bowls, and other utensils after eating.

examples.label: Cook food
examples.value: To prepare meals using various ingredients.

examples.label: Fetch water
examples.value: To go and bring water, often from a well or common tap.

examples.label: Feed animals
examples.value: To give food to cows, goats, chickens, or pets.

examples.label: Wash clothes
examples.value: To clean dirty clothes with soap and water.

examples.label: Water the plants
examples.value: To give water to plants in the garden.

examples.label: Go shopping
examples.value: To buy things from the market or a shop.

usage_examples: My sister helps to **clean the house** every morning.
I **wash the dishes** after dinner.
My mother **cooks food** for the whole family.
We **fetch water** from the village well.
My father **feeds the animals** before going to the field.
I help my mother **collect firewood**.
My elder brother **waters the plants** in our garden.
My grandmother **cares** for the younger **children**.
We **support** each other in all **household** tasks.
Everyone needs to **cooperate** to keep our **home** clean.
On Sundays, my mother **washes clothes**.
My father **goes shopping** for groceries once a week.
I help **sweep the floor** with a broom.
My sister **makes the beds** in the morning.
We all help to **look after** our home.

sections.text: We can use descriptive words (adjectives) to talk about how people help or their qualities at home.

examples.label: Helpful
examples.value: Likes to give assistance and make things easier.

examples.label: Hardworking
examples.value: Puts a lot of effort and energy into work.

examples.label: Caring
examples.value: Shows kindness and concern for others.

examples.label: Responsible
examples.value: Has duties and takes good care of them.

examples.label: Kind
examples.value: Being friendly, generous, and considerate.

examples.label: Supportive
examples.value: Giving encouragement and emotional help.

examples.label: Patient
examples.value: Able to accept delays or problems without becoming angry.

usage_examples: My mother is very **helpful** in everything.
My father is a **hardworking** farmer.
My grandmother is a **caring** person; she always worries about us.
My elder brother is very **responsible**; he always finishes his chores.
Be **kind** to your younger **siblings**.
Our **family** is very **supportive** of each other.
My **neighbor** is a **friendly** person.
Being **patient** helps us in many situations at home.
My sister is **loving** and always shares her toys.
My grandfather is a **wise** man.
Our parents are **understanding**.
A **cooperative** family is a happy family.
My teacher says I am a **disciplined** student.
It is important to be **honest** at home.
My aunt is very **generous**.

sections.text: Here are examples of simple conversations you might have with your family members in the morning and evening.

examples.label: Morning Dialogue
examples.value: Child: 'Good morning, Mother!' Mother: 'Good morning, my child. Did you sleep well?' Child: 'Yes, I slept well.'

examples.label: Evening Dialogue
examples.value: Father: 'What are you doing, children?' Children: 'We are playing a game, Father.' Father: 'Okay, it's time for dinner soon.'

examples.label: Asking about Food
examples.value: Child: 'Mother, what is for dinner today?' Mother: 'Today, I have cooked dal and rice.'

examples.label: Asking About School
examples.value: Parent: 'How was school today?' Child: 'It was good. I learned a new poem.'

examples.label: Offering to Help
examples.value: Child: 'You look tired, Mother. Can I help you?' Mother: 'Yes, please fetch me a glass of water.'

usage_examples: Child: '**It's time for dinner**!' Mother: 'Yes, come and eat.'
Father: '**Did you finish your homework**?' Son: 'Yes, Father, I finished it.'
Grandmother: '**How was your day** at school?' Grandchild: 'It was good, Grandmother.'
Mother: 'Please **help me with this work**.' Daughter: 'Yes, Mother, I will help you.'
We often have a **discussion** about our day during dinner.
Our family likes to **chat** about village news in the evening.
My parents **teach** me good manners.
Mother: '**Get ready for school**, it's getting late.'
Father: '**What did you learn today**?' Child: 'We learned about plants.'
Child: '**Good night, Father**.' Father: '**Good night, son. Sleep well**.'
Sister: '**Where is my book**?' Brother: 'It is on the table.'
Mother: '**What would you like for breakfast**?' Child: 'I would like roti and sabzi.'
We **tell each other** about our problems.
Father: '**Let's go to the market**.' Family: 'Okay, let's go!'
It is important to **communicate** with your family.

subtopics.title: 4.2. Offering and Asking for Help at Home

sections.text: In a family, we always help each other. Use these phrases to offer help or ask for it politely.

examples.label: Offering Help 1
examples.value: Mother: 'This pot is heavy.' Child: 'Can I help you, Mother?'

examples.label: Offering Help 2
examples.value: Father: 'I need to repair the fence.' Son: 'Let me help you, Father.'

examples.label: Asking for Help 1
examples.value: Child: 'I cannot open this jar.' Father: 'Father, please help me with this jar.'

examples.label: Asking for Help 2
examples.value: Sister: 'I can't reach the top shelf.' Brother: 'Could you please get that box for me?'

examples.label: Asking for an Item
examples.value: Child: 'Mother, can you give me some water?' Mother: 'Here, drink this.'

usage_examples: Father: 'I am going to the farm.' Son: '**Can I help you**, Father?'
Brother: 'I can't lift this.' Sister: '**Help me with this work**, please.'
Mother: 'Please bring the vegetables.' Child: '**Okay, Mother**.'
We always **share** our food with each other.
It's good to **cooperate** in **household** duties.
My family always **supports** me.
Daughter: 'Mother, **shall I wash the dishes**?'
Son: 'I can't solve this math problem. **Can you help me**?'
When you see someone working, you can ask: '**Do you need any help**?'
Mother: '**Please pass me the salt**.'
Child: 'Grandfather, I will carry your bag. **Let me take that**.'
It feels good to **assist** others in the family.
We **work together** to finish the chores quickly.
Asking '**What can I do to help**?' is a good way to offer help.
Being **helpful** makes everyone happy at home.
